ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Form used/assessment name
Notes: e.g., Self-Report, Parent Form, Short Form, Revised Version

ElementDescription: The subject acknowledges having mental functions
The subject represents him/herself as a person with autonomous thoughts and feelings
The subject is able to define and distinguish his/her own cognitive operations, such as remembering, imagining, having fantasies, dreaming, desiring, deciding, foreseeing, and thinking
The subject is able to define and distinguish between his/her emotional states
The subject recognizes that the representation of the self and/or of the world is subjective and/or fallible and/or that his/her own opinions have changed or are changeable
The subject recognizes the representational nature of thoughts and the limited impact that expectations, thoughts, and desires have on reality

The subject recognizes that his/her behavior may be determined by one specific mode of cognitive and/or emotional functioning and admits he/she is influenced by social and/or interpersonal variables related to the context of his/her cognitive and/or emotional functioning, or related to his/her behavior

The subject is able to give a complete description of his/her own mental state and/or of the interpersonal processes in which he/she is involved, through his/her perception of cognitive and/or emotional elements
The subject is able to integrate his/her different modes of cognitive and/or emotional functioning into a coherent and complex narrative
The subject recognizes the existence of mental functions in others
The subject represents others as persons with autonomous thoughts and feelings
The subject is able to perceive other individuals' cognitive operations, such as remembering, imagining, having fantasies, dreaming, awaiting, foreseeing, meditating
The subject is able to perceive other individuals' emotional states
The subject considers his/her own representations of other individuals' mental states and functioning as subjective and hypothetical
The subject makes plausible inferences about other individuals' mental states and recognizes the communicative value or signs of attitude or behavior

The subject is able to give a complete description of other individuals' mental states and/or the interpersonal processes in which they are involved through the perception of cognitive and/or emotional elements
The subject is able to integrate other individuals' different modes of cognitive and/or emotional and/or relational functioning into a coherent narrative

The subject recognizes that he/she is not necessarily at the center of other individuals' thoughts, feelings and emotions and/or that their actions stem from goals and reasons mostly independent of the relationships they have with the subject
The subject recognizes that other individuals may perceive events in a different way from his/her own and/or interpret them differently

The subject recognizes that variables, such as time, individual development, and experiences, determine the modes of the mental functioning of other individuals and/or recognizes that personal and relational events influence their processes and mental states
The subject discusses his own behavior and psychological processes and relates them, not as simple matter-of-fact data, but as tasks to be done and problems to be solved
The subject is able to define the terms of the problem in a plausible way
The subject tries to act directly on the problem state by modifying the general state of his/her organism
The subject avoids the occurrence of problem states and/or uses the relational context as a support
The subject tackles the problem voluntarily by imposing a certain type of behavior on him/herself or inhibiting it
The subject tackles the problem voluntarily by adjusting his mental order
The subject tackles the problem by acting upon the evaluations and beliefs which are at the basis of the problem itself and/or by using his/her general knowledge of his/her own mental functioning
The subject tackles the interpersonal dimension of the problem by using his/her own general knowledge of other people's mental functioning
The subject tackles the problem by accepting his/her own limits in managing his/her own self and influencing events
Metacognition Assessment Scale - Self Reflectivity score
Metacognition Assessment Scale - Understanding the Other's Mind score
Metacognition Assessment Scale - Decentration score
Metacognition Assessment Scale - Mastery score
Metacognition Assessment Scale - Total score
Notes: Sum of metacognition_self, metacognition_other, metacognition_decentration, and metacognition_mastery
